awd_titl_txt: Electrospinning Nanofiber Mats from Aqueous Polyelectrolyte Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrospinning is a well-established technique used to manufacture non-woven fiber mats comprised of nano- and micro-scale diameter fibers. Due to their high porosity and surface area, the fiber mats are promising materials for medical, environmental, and energy applications. While mats have been electrospun from over 100 different polymers, nearly all reports on the electrospinning of charged polymers have utilized toxic solvents in the precursor electrospinning solution and/or poisonous molecules post-production to make the mats chemically robust. This award supports fundamental research into the development of chemically robust nanofiber mats electrospun from aqueous polyelectrolyte solutions. The new aqueous precursor solutions will use salt to enable the preparation of thermally and chemically robust fibers without the use of toxic solvents, crosslinkers, or post-processing. Using green chemistry to manufacture polyelectrolyte nanofiber mats that can encapsulate cargo such as small molecule compounds, will broadly impact the design of multifunctional fiber scaffolds for a broad range of applications, including, wound healing and active food packaging. The U.S. economy and society will benefit from the production of safer materials that is enabled by this research. In addition to the technical achievements, this research will educate, provide research experiences, and mentor a diverse workforce at the emerging interface of chemical engineering, fiber science, and polymer physics. This research will result in numerous new research experiences and an enhanced engineering education for women and underrepresented groups.

The full application potential of electrospun non-woven polyelectrolyte fiber mats cannot be realized due to the dependence of the manufacturing process on toxic solvents and/or cytotoxic crosslinking agents. This research will provide a critical translation between the processing, structure, and properties of aqueous polyelectrolyte solutions electrospun into chemically robust fiber mats. Electrospinning precursor solutions will be comprised of complex coacervates, which are dense, polyelectrolyte-rich liquids that result from the electrostatic complexation of oppositely-charged polymers in water. The research team will establish parametric design rules for the electrospinning of polyelectrolyte fibers by correlating electrospinning with thermodynamic phase behavior and the rheological properties of a model coacervate system. Additionally, the partitioning and loading of hydrophilic and hydrophobic cargo into the precursor solutions and electrospun fibers will be established as a function of the hydrophobicity of the polyelectrolytes and the cargo. Chemically and thermally robust cargo-carrying fiber mats hold tremendous potential in applications where green materials are imperative, such as, wound healing, water remediation, catalysis, and food packaging.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this NSF CMMI award was to conduct fundamental research into the preparation of chemically robust fabrics that circumvent the reliance on organic solvents. Electrospinning is a well-established technique used to manufacture non-woven fiber mats comprised of nano- and micro-scale diameter fibers. Due to their high porosity and surface area, the fiber mats are promising materials for medical, environmental, and energy applications. Unfortunately, nearly all reports on the electrospinning of charged polymers have used toxic solvents in the precursor electrospinning solution and/or poisonous molecules post-production to make the mats chemically stable. Our approach was to design new aqueous precursor solutions that used salts instead of toxic solvents, crosslinkers, or post-processing. By using sustainable, green chemistry we were able to manufacture polyelectrolyte nanofiber mats from synthetic and natural polymers that were stable over a wide range of pH values, ionic strength conditions, and many organic solvents, but could be recycled via treatment with very high salt concentration. We determined that the mechanism that drives the electrospinnability of our polyelectrolyte/salt solutions is fundamentally different from what drives traditional electrospinning (i.e., polymer chain entanglements). Additionally, by using six fluorescent dyes as model cargo, we understand how to prepare value-added multifunctional fiber scaffolds for a broad range of applications, including, wound healing and active food packaging. Overall this work served as the scientific and inspirational basis for the development of a new class of greener and potentially more recyclable materials for use in a range of applications.

This project provided research opportunities for two graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, and four undergraduate researchers. To-date this award has resulted in five peer-reviewed manuscripts, two graduate dissertations, and two US patents. We presented our results at numerous conferences at the national and international level. From this project, the PIs have participated in numerous mentoring events hosted by the Graduate Women in STEM (GWIS), the Society of Women Engineers (SWE), the American Institute for Chemical Engineers, as well as panel events, for example "Sexual Harassment in the Workplace - It Could Happen to You Too" and one on "Mental Health", which were well-attended by undergraduate student organizations (Out in STEM, Society of American Military Engineers, SWE, National Society of Black Engineers, and the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers).  The PIs also participated in outreach through the Summer Engineering Institute for High School students (SENGI).


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Jessica Schiffman

Image
  • False colored scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of one gray human hair sitting on top of many red nanofibers electrospun from an aqueous polyelectrolyte solution. Look how small the electrospun fibers are compared to the human hair!
    Xiangxi (Zoey) Meng, Sarah L. Perry, Jessica D. Schiffman
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Jessica Schiffman
    Nanofibers electrospun from an aqueous polyelectrolyte solution
